items.title: Hey, how many C's are there in JavaScript?
items.content:
#â€‹705 â€” September 19, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScriptâ„¢? Weekly

'Oracle, Itâ€™s Time to Free JavaScript.' â€” Itâ€™s long been a bone of contention that Oracle owns the trademark for â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ (we put out a call two years ago) but this marks the first serious effort to try and change that, including petitioning the USPTO, if necessary. You can support the effort by signing this open letter, joining a vast array of JavaScriptÂ luminaries.

The JavaScript Community

Now You Can Compile and Run C in JavaScript â€” Well, if youâ€™re using Bun, at least. Bun v1.1.28 lands experimental support for compiling and native C code and then running its functions fromÂ JavaScript. It's easier than itÂ sounds..

Jarred Sumner (Bun)

ğŸ˜… Bun's creator said this is "an unplanned feature I worked on mostly a month ago on a Saturday for fun" â€“ that's our kindaÂ fun!

âœ‚ï¸ Cut Your QA Cycles Down from Hours to Minutes with QA Wolf â€” If slow QA processes bottleneck your software engineering team and youâ€™re releasing slower because of it, you must check out QA Wolf. QA Wolf gets engineering teams to 80% automated end-to-end test coverage and helps them ship 2x faster by reducing QA cycles from hours to minutes. LearnÂ more.

QA Wolf sponsor

ts-blank-space: Fast Type-Stripping TypeScript to JS Compiler â€” Itâ€™s job is simple: be the fastest TS to JS compiler written in JS (itâ€™s 5.6x faster than tsc.) Types are simply replaced with whitespace preserving the coordinates of the JS code which eliminates the need for sourcemapsÂ entirely.

Ashley Claymore / Bloomberg

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ† Developer analyst firm RedMonk has put out a Q3 2024 ranking of programming languages with JavaScript happily in firstÂ place.

  • ğŸ“º Honeypot has released a nine minute documentary where Ryan Dahl (the original creator of Node.js) and Bert Belder â–¶ï¸ tell the story of how Deno began.

  • Talking of Deno, Deno 2.0 is expected to be released tomorrow.

  • ğŸ§­ Alongside new releases of macOS, iOS, and iPadOS, Safari 18 has been released. Alongside numerous Web API enhancements, its JS regex support has been enhanced when it comes toÂ Unicode.

  • ğŸ”¥ David Bushell tried JSR â€“ he didn't like it.

RELEASES:

  • Fastify v5 â€“ Fastify is a popular, perf-focused web framework for Node.js, inspired by Express (which recently reached v5.0 too!)

  • Astro 5 Beta â€“ Astro helps keep the run of v5.0 releases going..

  • Node.js v22.9 (Current) â€“ Adds a util.getCallSite function to obtain the stacktrace of the current execution. V8's Maglev JIT is also disabled for reliability reasons due to outstanding issues inÂ V8.

  • Hono 4.6 â€“ The nifty 'any runtime' webapp framework gains context storageÂ middleware.

ViteConf is October 3rd! â€” StackBlitz is r(ai)sing the bar in the ViteConf '24 keynote. You wonâ€™t want to miss itÂ ğŸ‘€.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Mathematical Symbols and JavaScript Equivalents â€” Weâ€™re not just talking the obvious like + and - but things like â¿âˆš, Î£, Î , âˆƒ, and setÂ notation.

Joshua Nussbaum

A React 19 Cheat Sheet â€” From Kent C Dodds, of Epic React fame, comes this part cheat sheet, part succinct reminder of some of the new things you can do in ReactÂ 19, along with (very) brief codeÂ examples.

Kent C. Dodds

[Workshop] Fix Your Front-End 101: JavaScript Edition â€” Learn practical tips to debug JavaScript end to end. Join our JavaScript team live on SeptÂ 24.

Sentry sponsor

From Parcel to Vite: A Short Story of a 100K LOC Migration â€” â€œWeâ€™ve migrated our frontend projects from Parcel to Vite, and the process wasâ€¦ smooth.â€

Gao / Logto

How to Create a Chrome Extension with React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS and Vite â€” Covers everything you need to know right through to publishing in the Chrome WebÂ Store.

Lokman Musliu

ğŸ“º Building a React-Powered TODO App in 9 Steps â€“ A 54 second video showing off the key stages, all without any libraries exceptÂ React. Danny Thompson

ğŸ“„ 12 Ways to Better Vue Components with TypeScript Fotis Adamakis

ğŸ“„ Why We Switched from Cypress to Playwright S Varun (BigBinary)

ğŸ“„ Bitwise Operators in JavaScript and When to Use Them 8 Hobbies

ğŸ“„ An Introduction to TanStack Router Adam Rackis

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

date-fns v4.0 Released with First-Class Time Zones Support â€” date-fns is a hugely popular and comprehensive suite of 200+ functions for working with dates in JavaScript, and now thereâ€™s first-class time zone supportÂ too.

Sasha Koss

ts-remove-unused: Remove Unused Code from TypeScript Projects â€” A tool that can auto-fix unused exports (removing export from the declaration or the whole declaration based on its usage) and delete modules that have no referenced exports. Knip is another mature tool in this space, though focused more on detecting the things you canÂ remove.

LINE

Amplify the Benefits of JWTs and Session Tokens â€” Learn how leveraging the benefits of both session token authentication and JWTs results in the best of bothÂ approaches.

Clerk sponsor

Next.js SaaS Starter: A Next.js Template for SaaS Webapps â€” A starter template for building a SaaS-style webapp using Next.js with authentication, Stripe integration, and a dashboard for users. It uses Postgres and Drizzle for the database and UI elements based on shadcn/ui andÂ Tailwind.

Lee Robinson (Vercel)

nano-spawn: Tiny Execa-Inspired Process Execution for Node.js â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Sindreâ€™s Execa for running commands from a Node app in a reliable manner, nano-spawn offers its core functionality in a smaller package.

Sindre Sorhus and ehmicky

DECK.GL: GPU-Powered Large-Scale Data Visualization Framework â€” Well suited to geospatial data visualization use cases that go beyond typical 2D views. There are plenty of examples to show it off. Can be used through both vanilla JS and ReactÂ interfaces.

OpenJS Foundation

Vue-Multiselect 3.1: A Complete 'Selecting Solution' for Vue.js â€” Thereâ€™s a lot on offer here, complete with SSR support, Vuex support, strong test coverage, and with noÂ dependencies.

Damian Dulisz et al.

Chokidar 4.0: Efficient Cross-Platform File Watching Node.js Library â€” Wraps around fs.watch / fs.watchFile and normalizes the events received, applies best practices, and presents an API that works the same acrossÂ platforms.

Paul Miller

  • Express.js 4.21 â€“ We featured Express.js 5.0 last week, but the widely deployed 4.x branch continues to getÂ updates.

  • â­ Starlight 0.28 â€“ Astroâ€™s official, all-in-one docs site builder.

  • Material UI 6.1 â€“ Independent React components using MaterialÂ Design.

  • Varlet 3.5 â€“ Material Design-inspired component library for VueÂ 3.

  • Preact 10.24 â€“ The 3KB React-compatibleÂ alternative.

  • NodeBB 3.9 â€“ Node.js based forumÂ system.

items.title: The heaviest npm packages
items.content:
#â€‹704 â€” September 12, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of ES5 on the Web â€” Some of the earlier JavaScript build tools focused on allowing developers to write modern JavaScript code that could still run on the browsers of the time by compiling code down to ES5. Time has moved on, but have the tools or popular libraries? Philip investigates, and shares someÂ recommendations.

Philip Walton

ğŸ“Š Â The Top 5000 npm Packages by Size, Downloads, and Traffic â€” An interesting Google Sheets spreadsheet listing the top 5000 npm packages by package size, weekly downloads, and weekly traffic. One package is responsible for 278 terabytes of traffic per week, but the top 5000 add up to several petabytes.

Google Sheets / danhorus

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half the Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.6 â€” The latest TypeScript has landed with full support for iterator helpers, support for arbitrary module identifiers, --noUncheckedSideEffectImports to import modules without importing any values, and more â€” all covered in the always thorough releaseÂ post.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

Is PHP the New JavaScript? â€” Iâ€™m no real fan of PHP, but thereâ€™s been a lot of discussion on social media around increased interest in PHP by developers whoâ€™d usually steer clear of it, largely thanks to Laravel. This post tells the basic story and explains what Laravel brings to theÂ table.

Dave Kiss (Mux)

IN BRIEF:

  • Cloudflare Workers has greatly improved its npm package support. The popular serverless platform now supports a lot more Node.js APIs.

  • ğŸ‰ They don't happen often, but Frontend Masters is currently running a sale on its courses, which now includes a JS performance learningÂ path.

  • The ESLint project has announced its latest version support policy with ESLint v8.x going into end of life next month.

  • ğŸ“… Vercel's Next.js Conf 2024 is taking place this October 24, both in person in San Francisco, as well asÂ online.

RELEASES:

  • Storybook 8.3 â€“ Frontend component and UIÂ workshop. Now with first class VitestÂ support.

  • ESLint 9.10 â€“ Now with types included.

  • pnpm 9.10, Jasmine 5.3, Relay 18.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types â€” An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is puttingÂ forward.

Alex Harri JÃ³nsson

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more. Just added support for Node.js built-in node:testÂ framework!

Wallaby Team sponsor

Building the Same App Using Various Web Frameworks â€” A scientist at Amazon who usually works in Python with a minimum of JavaScript on the frontend wondered if a more modern web framework would suit him better in 2024. To try this out, he tried Next.js, SvelteKit, and the Python-flavored FastHTML.

Eugene Yan

Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools â€” A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of yourÂ site.

Umar Hansa (DebugBear)

React and FormData â€” FormData is ironically both the â€˜newest and yet oldestâ€™ standard for accessing form data. Here are some practical ways for using it withÂ TypeScript.

Brad Westfall

Automate Neon Schema Changes with Drizzle and GitHub Actions â€” Learn about schema migrations and how they can be applied to a Neon database with Drizzle and GitHubÂ Actions.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ“„ The Secrets of JavaScript's delete Operator Zachary Lee

ğŸ“„ Deploying a Next.js App to Production on Any Server Kurta Payjama

ğŸ“„ How to Create a Weekly Google Analytics Report That Posts to Slack Paul Scanlon

ğŸ“„ Top 10 Angular Architecture Mistakes You Really Want To Avoid Tomas Trajan

ğŸ“„ How to Fix ESLint Violations with AI Assistance Docker Labs

ğŸ“º Why You Should Use Redux in 2024 Mark Erikson

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Biome v1.9 Released; Turns One Year Old â€” Biome started life as a fork of Rome, a bold attempt to create an all-in-one â€˜frontend toolchainâ€™. As of v1.9, Biome can format and lint CSS, GraphQL, and JavaScript, does it very quickly, yet has 97% compatibility withÂ Prettier.

Victorien Elvinger & Biome Core Team

Express.js 5.0 Released â€” The seminal Node.js webapp library seemed to take a nap for a few years, but development was reinvigorated earlier this year. v5.0 brings a variety of modern tweaks and dependency updates, though it's still tagged next at the npm registry. (Official homepage and v5.x APIÂ docs.)

Wesley Todd

âœ‚ï¸ Cut Your QA Cycles Down from Hours to Minutes â€” QA Wolf's AI-native approach gets engineering teams to 80% automated end-to-end test coverage and helps them ship 2x faster by reducing QA cycles from hours toÂ minutes.

QA Wolf sponsor

Jimp 1.6: Manipulate Images without Native Dependencies â€” Most image libraries, such as Sharp, use native dependencies to do the heavy lifting, but Jimp can handle numerous formats directly for blurring, color tweaks, resizing, rotation, etc. Originally for Node, Jimp now works in the browser too â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

jimp Contributors

Valtio 2.0: Proxy State Made Simple â€” Turns objects into self-aware proxies so you can access state and subscribe to changes outside of components, add computed properties and more. Designed for React and compatible with Suspense, but can also be used with vanilla JS. â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

Daishi Kato

Violentmonkey: A Way to Run Userscripts in the Browser â€” There have been many extensions to run your own custom JavaScript automatically on certain Web pages over the years, but Violentmonkey seems to currently be one of the better and well maintained open source ones. GitHubÂ repo.

Violentmonkey Team

  • ğŸ” Orama 2.1 â€“ Dependency-free, full-text and vector search engine for all JSÂ runtimes, with typo tolerance, filters, facets, stemming, andÂ more.

  • create-fastify 5.0 â€“ Rapidly generate a Fastify project. It just takes npmÂ initÂ fastifyÂ app_name to getÂ started.

  • file-type 19.5 â€“ Detect the file type of a file, stream, orÂ data. Now with WebVTTÂ support.

  • TWGL.js 6.1 â€“ Helpers for working with low-level WebGL fromÂ JS.

  • ğŸ¨ Chroma.js 3.1 â€“ JavaScript color manipulationÂ library.

  • Pixi.js 8.4 â€“ Fast, flexible 2D WebGL renderer.

items.title: Reverse engineering minified JS with ChatGPT
items.content:
#â€‹703 â€” September 5, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

An SSR Performance Showdown â€” Fastifyâ€™s Matteo Collina set out to find the current state of server-side rendering performance across todayâ€™s most popular libraries. The first attempt faced negative feedback due to implementation issues, but the showdown has been improved andÂ re-run.

Matteo Collina

Announcing Vue 3.5 â€” While v3.5 is a minor release, itâ€™s one Vue users will love, with big performance and memory usage improvements in its reactivity system. With no breaking changes, upgrade and watch memory consumptionÂ drop.

Evan You

WorkOS: The Modern Identity Platform for B2BÂ SaaS â€” WorkOS is a modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible and easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and RBAC in minutes instead of months. It's trusted by hundreds of high-growth startups such as Perplexity, Vercel, Drata, andÂ Webflow.

WorkOS sponsor

Reverse Engineering Minified JavaScript with ChatGPT â€” Writing new code with AI is one thing, but could it be even better at understanding existing code that youâ€™re struggling toÂ grok? Yes, itÂ seems.

Frank Fiegel

Inside ECMAScript: JavaScript Standards Get an Extra Stage â€” After nine years of annual updates, TC39 has tweaked the process to make rolling out new features faster and smoother. The so-called â€˜Stage 2.7â€™ has been around for a while, but this is a neat primer to what itÂ represents.

Mary Branscombe (The New Stack)

IN BRIEF:

  • â­ Vercel goes deep into what's new in React 19.

  • ğŸ’° Alpine.js creator Caleb Porzio shares his tale of passing $1m on GitHubÂ Sponsors.

  • Bye NgModules, the future of Angular is standalone! Angular v19 will make standalone: true the default for components, directives, and pipes. This is already the recommended best practice,Â however.

  • Angular's product lead, Minko Gechev, has also shared a little about what it means to mange the Angular project.

  • OpenAI has switched ChatGPT from Next.js to a Remix-based app, according to Remix's Ryan Florence on X.

  • ğŸ‡µğŸ‡± Poland's WarsawJS community is holding a 10th anniversary meetup on September 11. They invite you to â–¶ï¸ watch live on YouTube.

  • ğŸ¤– Lee Robinson shows off â–¶ï¸ the latest enhancements to Vercel's v0, an AI-based tool for creating apps and components from prompts youÂ supply.

[Workshop] Fix Your Front-End: JavaScript Edition â€” Learn practical tips to make debugging more tolerable. Join our JavaScript team live for a masterclass on SeptÂ 24.

Sentry sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v22.8.0 (Current) â€“ Adds a new API for enabling on-disk code caching at runtime, as well as options to set thresholds for code coverageÂ success.

  • Astro 4.15 â€“ The popular content site framework stabilizes Astro Actions, a solution for fully type-safe backendÂ functions.

  • Jimp 1.3 â€“ Pure JS image processing library forÂ Node.

  • Turborepo 2.1, Puppeteer 23.3, Mermaid 11.1

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

â–¶Â Â Behind the Scenes: The Making of VS Code â€” A detailed conversation with two of the popular editor's principal engineers on what makes it tick. VS Code is surely one of the world's most widely distributed JavaScript-powered apps.

Holland, Rieken and Pasero (Microsoft)

How I Created a 3.78MB Docker Image for a JavaScript Service â€” The smallest JavaScript app container images tend to run into tens of megabytes, but tailoring your app to run on a lighter runtime like llrt can yield striking results.

Shenzilong

Leave Forms to SurveyJS and Get Back to What You Love Coding â€” Extensible JavaScript libraries for form management. Drag-and-drop UI, JSON form definitions, and seamless integration with any backend for full dataÂ control.

SurveyJS sponsor

Exploring Goja: A Go-Powered JavaScript Runtime â€” Goja is a pure Go(lang) JS runtime that makes it possible to embed JS into GoÂ apps.

JT Archie

How to Use React Compiler â€” The compiler feature in React 19 is generating a lot of buzz â€” this â€œcomplete guideâ€, as described by this author, covers much of what you'll need to getÂ started.

Tapas Adhikary

Multithreaded Programming in Node.js using Atomics â€” Worker threads enable you to write multi-threaded Node apps, but sharing resources across them can quickly become tricky. Atomics can help avoid some of theÂ pain.

Pavel Romanov

ğŸ“„ A Complete Guide to Beginning with JavaScript â€“ A rather epic article packed with background knowledge, context, and third party resources for starting a modern JavaScript learningÂ journey. Cody Lindley

ğŸ“„ Implementing Filtered Semantic Search Using pgvector and JavaScript Team Timescale

ğŸ“„ How to Quickly (and Weightlessly) Convert Chrome Extensions to Safari Nina Torgunakova (Evil Martians)

ğŸ“„ How Sentry Uses Mutation Testing on its JavaScript SDKs Lukas Stracke (Sentry)

ğŸ¤ Talking Deno 2 with Ryan Dahl Syntaxâ€¤fm Podcast

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

jsdiff 6.0: A JavaScript Text Diffing Implementation â€” Can compare strings for differences in various ways including creating patches. Thereâ€™s an onlineÂ demo. (Don't worry â€“ we're not going monthly ;-))

Kevin Decker

Redwood v8.0 Released â€” A long standing, opinionated React & GraphQL (and/or RSC) full-stack framework that covers all the bases for professional dev teams with best-in-class tool support. v8.0 introduces a background jobs system, Docker support, and easier SSR and RSCÂ setup.

Redwood Team

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous Is Here â€” Automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Backed by YC, CTO of GitHub, CPO of Adobe, CEO ofÂ Vercel.

Meticulous sponsor

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§Â GOV.UK Vue 1.0: Build Vue Apps, the British Way â€” The UK government is known for having an effective, well-designed site where Brits can complete various official tasks. Now you can get all of their components in Vue 3Â form.

UK Government

ğŸ‘€Â style-observer: A Mutation Observer for CSS â€” Attach JavaScript callbacks to changes in computed values of CSSÂ properties.

Bramus Van Damme

Goxygen: Quickly Generate a Go Backend for a JS Project â€” A tool that sets up a new Go-based project with Angular, React, or Vue in the front-end, and Docker and Docker Compose files to make it allÂ work.

Sasha Shpota

Typist 7.0: Tiptap-Based Rich Text Editor Component â€” Simple and opinionated. You can try several examples in the sidebar. Well suited for basic rich text situations like writing comments or messages and has a single-lineÂ mode.

Doist

Belt: A New Tool for Starting React Native Apps â€” A CLI tool for starting a new React Native app that takes various mundane decisions away from you and uses tooling and conventions established by a productive app developmentÂ team.

Thoughtbot

  • Tinybase 5.2 â€“ Powerful reactive data store for localâ€‘firstÂ apps. Now with PostgresÂ support (which can even workÂ in-browser!)

  • jsdoc-to-markdown 9.0 â€“ Generate Markdown docs from JSDoc-annotatedÂ code.

  • LogTape 0.5 â€“ No-dependency logging lib for Deno, Node, Bun & browsers.

  • Plasmo 0.89 â€“ Imagine Next.js but for building browserÂ extensions.

  • JsonTree.js 3.0 â€“ Customizable tree views for JSONÂ data.

  • Poku 2.6 â€“ Cross-platform JavaScript testÂ runner.

  • Faker 9.0 â€“ Generate large amounts of fakeÂ data.

items.title: JavaScript's Rust tool belt
items.content:
#â€‹702 â€” August 29, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Rspack 1.0: The Rust-Powered JavaScript Bundler â€” Far from being â€˜yet another bundlerâ€™ with its own approach and terminology to learn, Rspack prides itself on being webpack API and ecosystem compatible, while offering many times the performance. The team now considers it production ready and encourages you to try your webpack-based projects onÂ it.

Rspack Contributors

ğŸ’¡ Rspack also has a family of ancillary tools worth checking out, such as Rsdoctor, a tool for analyzing and visualizing your build process (for both Rspack and webpack!)

Front-End System Design â€” Learn to create scalable, efficient user interfaces in this extensive video course by Evgennii Ray. Explore the box model, browser rendering, DOM manipulation, state management, performance and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

How to Create an NPM Package in 2024 â€” Sounds simple, but there are a lot of steps involved if you want to follow best practices, introduce useful tools, and get things just right. Matt Pocock walks through the process here, and thereâ€™s a 14-minute screencast too, if youâ€™d prefer toÂ watchÂ along.

Matt Pocock

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¤– v0 is an AI-powered tool from Vercel for, originally, generating shadcn/ui-powered React components based upon prompts you supply. Now, however, it has basic Vue.js support too.

  • Deno 1.46 has been released and promises to be the final 1.x release before the much awaited Deno 2.0. Deno's Node compatibility improves even more (it now supports Playwright and many more things) and ships with V8 12.9.

  • ğŸ“Š IEEE has published its latest annual list of top programming languages. JavaScript takes third place, but TypeScript has leapt up several placesÂ toÂ fourth.

RELEASES:

  • Prisma 5.19 â€“ The popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript adds 'TypedSQL', a way to write raw SQL queries in a type-safeÂ way.

  • ğŸ“ˆ billboard.js 3.13 â€“ Popular D3 chart library adds area-step-rangeÂ charts.

  • pnpm 9.9 â€“ Fast, space efficient packageÂ manager.

  • React Email 3.0, Ember 5.11, Bun v1.1.26

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

JS Dates are About to Be Fixed â€” Handling dates and times is famously a painful area for programmers and JavaScript hasnâ€™t done a lot to make it easier. Libraries like Moment.js help a lot, but Iago looks at how the Temporal proposal and its features will begin to help a lot more overÂ time.

Iago Lastra

Weekly Chats on the Art and Practice of Programming â€” Your home for weekly conversations with fascinating guests about how technology is made andÂ where itâ€™sÂ headed.

The Stack Overflow Podcast sponsor

JavaScript Generators Explained â€” Jan was frustrated by the quality of documentation and articles explaining generators in JavaScript, and set out to explain things in a way that a more advanced developer couldÂ appreciate.

Jan Hesters

Implementing a React-a-Like from Scratch â€” While it's unlikely you'll actually want to do this, at least thinking about it can prove instructive as to whatâ€™s going on in Reactâ€™s engineÂ room.

Robby Pruzan

â–¶Â Â How to Implement the 2048 Game in JavaScript â€” Ania is back with one of her usual easy to follow walkthroughs of implementing a complete game in JavaScript. This time itâ€™s the 2048 sliding puzzle game. (Two weeks ago she did Tic-Tac-Toe asÂ well.)

Ania KubÃ³w

Learn Role-Based Access Control and Simplify PermissionsÂ Management â€” Enhance security and streamline access by managing user roles with ClerkÂ Organizations.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ“„ The Only Widely Recognized JS Feature Ever Deprecated â€“ Spoiler: Itâ€™s with. Trevor Lasn

ğŸ“„ Generating Unique Random Numbers in JavaScript Using Sets Amejimaobari

ğŸ“º 21 Talks from the Chain React 2024 Conference â€“ A React Native event. YouTube

ğŸ“„ Exposing Internal Methods on Vue Custom Elements Jaime Jones

ğŸ“„ The Interface Segregation Principle in React Alex Kondov

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

TypeScript 5.6 Release Candidate â€” As always, Daniel presents an epic roundup of whatâ€™s new. Weâ€™ll focus more on it next week though, as the final release is anticipated to land next Tuesday (SeptemberÂ 3).

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

Vuestic UI 1.10: A Vue.js 3.0 UI Framework â€” Features 60 customizable and responsive components and with the v1.10 release itâ€™s gained a significant bundle size optimization, a custom compiler that improves build time performance, and other minor enhancements. GitHubÂ repo.

Vuestic UI

âœ… Bye Bye Bugs â€” Get 80% automated E2E test coverage for mobile and web apps in under 4 months with QA Wolf. With QA cycles complete in minutes (not days), bugs donâ€™t stand a chance. Schedule aÂ demo.

QA Wolf sponsor

MaterialÂ UI v6: The Popular React UI Design/Component System â€” At ten years old, the popular design system has its latest major release. There's a focus on improved theming, color scheme management, container queries, and React 19 support. There are revamped templates to be inspiredÂ by,Â too.

GarcÃ­a, Bittu, Andai, et al.

npm-check-updates 17.0: Update package.json Dependencies to Latest Versions â€” That is, as opposed to the specified versions. It includes a handy -i interactive mode so you can look at potential upgrades and then opt in to them one byÂ one.

Raine Revere

Code Hike 1.0: Turn Markdown into Rich Interactive Experiences â€” Aimed at use cases like code walkthroughs and interactive docs, Code Hike bridges the gap between Markdown and React when creating technical content that takes full advantage of the modernÂ web.

Rodrigo Pombo

Calendar.js: A Calendar Control with Drag and Drop â€” A responsive calendar with no dependencies, full drag and drop support (even between calendars), and many ways to manage events with recurring events, exporting, holidays, andÂ more.

William Troup

  • ğŸ“Š Perspective 3.0 â€“ Data visualization and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly where it can be used fromÂ JavaScript. Their homepage shows it off well with a live example.

  • json-viewer 3.5 â€“ Display JSON data in a readable, user-friendlyÂ way.

  • â™Ÿï¸ Stockfish.js 16.1 â€“ A JavaScript chess engine.

  • jest-dom 6.5 â€“ Jest matchers to test DOMÂ state.

  • Marked 14.1 â€“ Fast Markdown compilerÂ /Â parser.

  • Javet 3.1.5 â€“ Java + V8. Embed JS intoÂ Java.

  • Pixi.js 8.3.4 â€“ Fast 2D on WebGLÂ engine.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
